data.title: Move non-portable thread check guards to specific platforms that use it.
data.body:
There was some code to ensure graphics code was only executing on the main thread on Android from commit 203a315. WinRT didn't support the threading check, so it had to be #ifdef'd out. It was done with a !WINRT or !DIRECTX check, though, causing platforms without the method to fail to compile. Since only OpenGL and PSM actually use it, I've moved the code to those specific areas and left them out of the main file.

I traced the calls back and see that TextureCollection.SetTextures is only ever called by PlatformApplyState, which seems like the logical place to move such a check.

Also, it may in fact be OpenGL-only, if any PSM devs are watching could they comment?

Memory optimization for Effects
data.body:
Effects keep a static copy of the shader Bytecode.
The 5 stock effects are about 100KB which could be significant on the
mobile. The bytecodes are already loader in memory as Resources in the
assembly, so loading them each time is not that slow.

The only slowdown could be the conversion from stream into byte array
inside LoadEffectResource(). This can be addressed by extending the
effect to accept streams. The Effect constructor converts the byte[]
into a stream/BinaryReader anyway so we could pass directly the stream
and avoid any data copy.

Added additional iOS application events to Game class
data.body:
## Overview

MonoGame already gives us access to these iOS app lifecycle events (through Game.Activated and Game.Deactivated):
- `applicationDidBecomeActive`
- `applicationWillResignActive`

But although MonoGame has callbacks for these additional iOS application events under the hood, there was previously no way to access them through the Game class:
- `applicationDidEnterBackground`
- `applicationWillEnterForeground`
- `applicationDidReceiveMemoryWarning`

This commit adds `EnterBackground`, `EnterForeground`, and `MemoryWarningReceived` events to the MonoGame Game class (conditionally compiled for IOS only).

I personally think it's good to be able to respond to these other events from XNA game code. For me, simply responding to Activated and Deactivated isn't ideal; my game saves constantly and aggressively, but I only occasionally want to upload my save data to the cloud (using iCloud on iOS). For me, applicationDidEnterBackground is the perfect time to do this, because it signals that the user is potentially quitting the game for a while (vs. simply deactivating the game, which might only last a second or two).
## Concerns

First of all, this is my first ever GitHub fork and commit, so I apologize if I screw this up. I hope I'm doing this right :)

Secondly, I noticed that some of the other custom Game event declarations use a `[CLSCompliant(false)]` attribute, for example:

``` C#
#if WINDOWS_STOREAPP
    [CLSCompliant(false)]
    public event EventHandler<ViewStateChangedEventArgs> ApplicationViewChanged;
#endif

#if WINRT
    [CLSCompliant(false)]
    public ApplicationExecutionState PreviousExecutionState { get; internal set; }
#endif
```

I'm not sure exactly what that attribute means. Should the event declarations I added for EnterBackground, EnterForeground, and MemoryWarningReceived also be decorated with the same attribute?

Mixed Licenses (MIT, Dual MSPL/LGPL, GPL!)
data.body:
So we've been doing a full sweep of the MG-SDL2 code, as part of the process of making FNA:

https://github.com/flibitijibibo/MonoGame

We're noticing a LOT of various files with varying licenses. Here are the ones we've found so far:
- LzxDecoder.cs is released under a dual MSPL/LGPL license. This one's fine, but I only noticed it once we were editing all the files in `Content/`. Might need to be noted somewhere.
- Various files throughout the project, particularly the ContentReaders, have the Mono.Xna license, the MIT license. Was this all re-licensed under the MSPL when the MonoGame project became a thing, or are these license headers accurate? In the latter case, this may need to be noted in the main LICENSE file.
- Vector4, SpriteFont and ReflectiveReader have code from SilverSprite, another MIT-licensed project. Same question as the Mono.Xna project, basically.

And while this doesn't quite affect the FNA project in the same way, now that I've rewritten the Audio engine there, I figured the MonoGame team ought to know: The XACT WaveBank implementation in MonoGame right now is a C# copy of Luigi Auriemma's unxwb project... which is released under the GPL. Far as I know, there's been no re-licensing of that code, so this could be a serious legal problem for a LOT of projects out there. I'm actually still auditing everything in MG-SDL2's XACT reimplementation to be sure that everything I got was from either MonoGame as brand new information (for instance, the byte-to-float volume calculation) or from a different source altogether (i.e. various wikis with bits and pieces of XACT binary info, published under a permissive license). But yeah, that was a fun discovery.

Anyway, this is what we've found so far; I'll update if we find any more oddities regarding licenses.

data.title: Proposal / Request for Feedback: Transition to a rolling release model
data.body:
So I was looking at the new MonoGame site and I've realised that the latest official release was 3.0.1, which is now quickly approaching over a year ago.  Looking at the differences between master and develop on GitHub reveals:

"This branch is 26 commits ahead and 1993 commits behind develop"

Originally I used to use the official releases, but transitioned to using development builds and eventually went to using MonoGame as a Git submodule.  While I've found that the latter option offers far more flexibility in terms of updating to get bug fixes, I still understand that some people like just referencing DLLs or binaries.

That said, I don't think the official versioned releases are offering a lot of value right now.  Although they're promoted on the downloads page, they've 1993 commits behind the latest development head.  That is **a lot** of work, both functionality and bug fixes, which aren't right now being promoted to people who are new to MonoGame.  A prime example of this is the work being done on the content pipeline, which is now reasonably usable (I use the APIs in my higher-level engine without issue) but is not available to users of 3.0.1.  I believe the last release date (3rd March 2013) also creates a perception of "no longer developed", even though this is far from the case.  

So the general proposal is something like this:
- Promote "develop" as the new stable, official version for people to be using.  That is, the installers and DLLs that are generated from the develop branch are the ones promoted on the website.
- The current official versioning is moved to an "older releases" section on the download page, with a note that MonoGame uses rolling releases (and hence there is no explicit versioning).
- This has the added advantage that any bug reports that are coming through are going to be relevant and up-to-date, and bug fixes can likely be fixed by people grabbing the latest DLLs (or updating the Git submodule).

What do people think of this proposal?

data.title: Prevent Protobuild synchronization from occurring
data.body:
Currently the MonoGame definition file is manually maintained (it has comments and grouping etc.), which means any Protobuild synchronisation with change the entire file (and it means Git will mark the repository as dirty, which is annoying as a Git sbumodule).

This prevents Protobuild from synchronizing C# projects back to the MonoGame definition under any circumstances, particularly:
- When --resync or --sync is used on the command line
- When Protobuild is being invoked with MonoGame as a submodule (where the parent module is resyncing)

The changes made in Protobuild.exe are in this commit: https://github.com/hach-que/Protobuild/commit/e4852cbb1f9c00f7eace1cf4f71f62c5c4657858

data.title: WinRT - Crash on exit when bad init occurs
data.body:
On WinRT, if your game does not make it into the graphics initialization code, meaning Game.IsActive is actually false, and then your game quits, MonoGame throws an exception from MetroGamePlatform.Dispose of type InvalidOperationException. This exception is raised because Game.graphicsDeviceManager is expected to return null, but instead throws an exception when the GDM is not initialized yet.

I suggest that the "throw new InvalidOperationException" code segment be constrained also by Game.IsActive, or some other indicator that the game has actually been constructed and an exception is expected. Otherwise, the errant game will just throw an unhandled exception upon exit, an exception that is entirely untraceable in the debugger.

data.title: Fixed measure string to return correct width if spacing is used
data.body:
MeasureString did not return the correct width because it was calculating width like this (S denotes spacing, C denoes character):
S C S C
XNA calculates spacing like this:
S C S C S

This is a comparison of XNA's and MonoGame's behaviour when text boxes are aligned to the right.
![comparison](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/431167/2381020/da4fe5dc-a8b7-11e3-8e62-213b5b72dadf.png)

With this fix the images line up perfectly.
